thread.title: Most City of Industry council members work for the city’s highest paid contractors
thread.title_full: Most City of Industry council members work for the city’s highest paid contractors

author: Jason Henry
title: Most City of Industry council members work for the city’s highest paid contractors
text:
When former Industry Councilman Jeff Parriott lost his $88,000 job with the city’s redevelopment agency, he switched from coordinating Industry’s development projects to archiving historical photographs at the city-owned Homestead Museum.
The former council member made a seamless transition, starting as the museum’s operator weeks before collecting his final check from the Industry Urban Development Agency, according to his payment history and his economic disclosures.
For both jobs, Parriott’s salary was paid using funds that came from the city he represented.
Close ties to companies with lucrative contracts with the city are common in Industry, where the city’s three new council members pledged to investigate claims of corruption and cronyism, but then could not vote to pay all of the city’s bills at their first meeting because each of their bosses appeared on the list.
Parriott stepped down in late August to focus on his “familial responsibilities and ongoing professional obligations,” according to a letter to the council.
Today, four out of five council members, including Parriott’s replacement, get paid by some of the city’s highest-paid contractors. Those companies made $2.6 million in the past five months.
While it’s not uncommon to have occasional conflicts, Industry’s situation is out of the ordinary, said Kathy Feng, executive director of California Common Cause, a government watchdog group.
“In the city of Industry, for four out of five of the electeds to be employed by contracting companies is not a coincidence, it’s part of a pattern that the city has employed, where kickbacks and corruption are the name of the game,” Feng said.
The close ties raise questions about whether the council makes decisions to benefit the public or to benefit themselves, Feng said. Industry has so few residents and such strict control over housing that it makes it hard for a healthy democracy to exist, she said.
“It becomes something where they can continue to milk the system with so little scrutiny,” she said. “These are very much industry towns, not unlike what we might have had centuries ago, where people feel very beholden to the city bosses, in every sense of the word.”
California Attorney General Kamala Harris’ office declined to comment on the legality, referring only to its conflict of interest guide.
The guide states that a public official must disqualify himself or herself from a decision that affects their source of income. The council does recuse themselves, with each of the four members doing so monthly, according to meeting minutes.

“The council members themselves don’t have an ownership interest in these entities, they’re employees. Their financial interest would arguably be their paycheck,” said City Attorney Jamie Casso. “They recuse themselves out of an abundance of caution should there be any conflict of interest, potential or actual.”
A recusal doesn’t resolve the “fundamental conflict of interest,” Feng said.
“If one person recuses themselves, there are so many people that have their fingers in the cookie jar that the conflict still exists,” she said.
Jessica Levinson, a law professor at Loyola Law School and president of the Los Angeles City Ethics Commission, said the number of council members with conflicts seemed unusual, but that she would be more worried if they didn’t recuse themselves or disclose their ties.
“In a perfect world, you get invested, well-qualified people who don’t have any personal stake in the city other than wanting to do a good job, but no one lives in that perfect world,” Levinson said. “Some of this is bound to happen, but the number is particularly high in this case, and the relationship is particularly direct.”
Since 2012, Parriott has worked for Historical Resources Inc, a for-profit company whose only client is the city’s Homestead Museum. Historical Resources receives more than $250,000 quarterly from Industry. The city couldn’t say how much Parriott makes, as it claims it doesn’t maintain Historical Resources’ financial records. Historical Resources, however, says it does.
Neither could provide Parriott’s salary; his economic interest forms list only a vague $10,000 to $100,000 range.
Both Mayor Mark Radecki and appointed Councilman Abraham Cruz work as salaried supervisors for Square Root Golf & Landscape, which makes about $200,000 a month from Industry. It’s one of two landscaping companies paid millions each year in the 12-square-mile city. Square Root’s co-owner Bert Spivey serves on the planning commission.
Radecki previously did work for former Mayor David Perez, who came under investigation by the district attorney and the state controller after an audit found his companies made $326 million from its contracts with Industry over the past two decades.
Perez’s family backed Radecki in the election, along with Cory Moss and Newell Ruggles. Moss works for CNC Engineering, which collects about $400,000 from the city every month. CNC Engineering, a consultant on most of Industry’s major projects, has operated the Industry Hills Expo Center at a significant loss for years, according to the city.
Ruggles works for Haddick’s Towing and Autobody, which maintains the city’s fleet of vehicles and handles towing for the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department’s Industry station. It made about $6,000 directly from the city since June, according to check registers voted on by the council.
Only Ruggles responded to calls for comment.
“Industry, it’s a very small community,” he said. “Everybody is connected in one way or another.”
